column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction

#Text=Adult spinal deformity ( ASD ) is a broad diagnosis referring to stable asymptomatic curves and disabling deformities in the spine that contribute to pain , weakness , and low health-related quality of life ( HRQOL ) .
#Text=Although ASD is quite common , the variation and unique pattern of each spinal deformity make reproducible measurement difficult .
#Text=Previous studies investigating the correlation between radiographic appearances and clinical symptoms yielded rather low predictive power due to highly variable health status .
#Text=Little correlation between radiographic assessment and questionnaire scores was found for adolescent idiopathic scoliosis .
#Text=However , in 2005 , Glassman et al. showed that sagittal plane balance is the most reliable predictor of clinical symptoms in adults with spinal deformity .
#Text=Even mild positive sagittal balance results in destructive spinal deformity , clinical symptoms of which deteriorate linearly .
#Text=Therefore , a surgical plan for restoring sagittal balance is crucial in all spinal reconstructive surgeries .
#Text=Parameters to describe the sagittal alignment of the spine include the sagittal vertical axis ( SVA ) , thoracic kyphosis , lumbar lordosis , pelvic incidence , pelvic tilt , and sacral slope .

#Text=SVA , which is the most commonly used measure of the sagittal plane , is obtained from standing lateral radiographs and is defined as the horizontal distance between two landmarks : the center of C7 vertebral body and the posterior superior aspect of the S1 vertebral body .

#Text=According to Schwab ’s classification based on Jean Dubousset‘s cone of economy , the realignment of the spine should aim to meet the criteria of SVA < 50 mm to alleviate sensations of falling over .
#Text=Consequently , formulating a patient-specific surgical plan requires SVA measurement both preoperatively and postoperatively , using whole-spine lateral radiographs .
#Text=However , manual SVA estimation on radiographs is rather inconvenient due to lack of easy-to-use tools .
#Text=To solve this issue , we propose using deep-learning models for fully automatic estimation of SVA .
#Text=A well-known family of deep-learning models is the convolutional neural networks ( CNNs ) .
#Text=CNNs have drawn considerable attention since 2012 , as they were found to outperform traditional image processing algorithms on image classification tasks .
#Text=Since then , CNNs have been increasingly used for medical image analysis .
#Text=A CNN is primarily made of stacked convolution layers , which can be regarded as a series of learnable feature extractors designed for acquiring low-to-high-level features of an image .
#Text=In general , basic image features , such as blob of colors or edges of different orientations , are learnable by the shallow convolution layers .
#Text=On the other hand , complex image features , such as appearances of objects , are learnable by the deep convolution layers .
#Text=Therefore , well-trained convolution layers can be used to extract informative features that are useful for landmark localization or other specific tasks .
#Text=Automatic SVA estimation can generally be regarded as the task of landmark localization , as SVA was defined as the horizontal difference between two anatomical landmarks .
#Text=In this study , we investigated the performance of ResUNet for automatic vertebrae localization on radiographs .
#Text=ResUNet is a variant of CNN .

#Text=Its UNet-like structure combines the contextual information produced by deep layers and better location information produced by shallow layers , allowing better utilization of low- and high-level features .
#Text=In addition , the encapsulated residual blocks of ResUNet enable better flow of information and can avoid performance deterioration as the network goes deeper .
#Text=ResUNet has been used for cell segmentation from biomedical images and road extraction from satellite images .
#Text=To the best of our knowledge , our study is the first to utilize ResUNet for anatomical landmark localization .
#Text=Some previous works use CNN for vertebrae segmentation or localization .
#Text=For example , for 3D CT and MR images , Lessmann et al. used a 3D UNet-like model for vertebrae segmentation .
#Text=In addition , Wimmer et al. used 3D CNN for vertebrae localization .

#Text=There were also studies on radiographs : for biplanar radiographs , including A-P and lateral view , Gallbusera et al. used a database collected using the EOS™ imaging system and trained CNN models for each of the landmarks .
#Text=For lateral spine radiographs , Al Arif et al. applied a UNet model for the localization of cervical vertebral centers .
#Text=In this study , we applied ResUNet on plain lateral spine radiographs .
#Text=Although our algorithm is similar to the one in , there are some major differences .

#Text=First , we did not split images into patches , as patching leads to extra pre- and post-processing steps , and the correlation between landmarks of different patches will be ignored completely .
#Text=However , if patching was not performed , the large image size would lead to insufficient amount of RAM on GPU .
#Text=To alleviate this issue , we used a small batch size ( batch size = 2 ) and replaced the widely used batch normalization with the group normalization in our network .
#Text=Group normalization is known to perform well even when the batch size is small , as it does not perform normalization along the batch axis .
#Text=Secondly , we let probability maps of landmarks to be predicted separately .
#Text=Thus , predictions were not on the same map and further post-processing steps involving separation and identification of the landmarks can be eliminated .
